## 2.

API-First Architecture Expectations

The platform will adopt an **API-first architecture**, meaning all core functionality is exposed via well-designed APIs before anything else.
Every service – from customer onboarding to transaction processing – will be accessible through RESTful API endpoints.

These include regression-based methods like Linear Regression, tree-based models such as Decision Trees and Random Forests, and instance-based learners like K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN).15 Support Vector Machines (SVM), known for their effectiveness in classification and regression tasks, have also shown promise in predicting stock price directions.15 Ensemble methods like Random Forests and boosting algorithms like XGBoost are also frequently used and can offer high accuracy.15In recent years, deep learning techniques have gained significant traction in financial forecasting.

Automated Expense Categorization (AI-powered):
An ideal expense management system should leverage artificial intelligence (AI) to automatically categorize expenses based on the provided description.1 For instance, when a user enters "lunch with client," the AI should recognize keywords and context to appropriately categorize it, such as "Meals and Entertainment" or "Client Meetings," without requiring manual selection from an extensive list.10 This automation significantly reduces the time employees spend on expense reports and ensures more consistent categorization across the organization.

Furthermore, the AI should possess the ability to learn from past entries and merchant information, thereby improving its accuracy over time.9 If the user frequently categorizes similar expenses under a specific project or cost center, the AI should learn this pattern and suggest or automatically apply it to future entries.

errors.sentence: The need to define transformation rules for every possible combination of operations can also introduce scalability challenges as the platform's features expand.16Alternatively, the Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDT) model employs specialized data structures that inherently manage concurrent edits without generating conflicts, thereby ensuring eventual consistency across all replicas in a distributed system.21 CRDTs allow users to make independent changes to their local document copies, and these changes are automatically merged when the replicas synchronize.22 This model supports peer-to-peer architectures, offering resilience to network disruptions and enabling offline editing capabilities.21 Libraries like Yjs and Automerge provide frameworks for building CRDT-based collaborative features.21 While CRDTs simplify conflict resolution, they may present limitations in accurately capturing the nuances of user intent in complex rich text editing scenarios compared to OT.18
context_before: The seamless and immediate reflection of changes across all collaborators' views necessitates a low latency data synchronization mechanism between the platform's clients and its underlying infrastructure, whether server-based or peer-to-peer.6 Optimization of network protocols, such as WebSockets which provide low-latency, bidirectional communication, and efficient data transmission strategies are therefore critical.8To ensure data integrity and a consistent user experience when multiple individuals edit concurrently, the platform must implement a robust conflict resolution strategy.7

Two primary models exist for achieving this: Operational Transformation (OT) and Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs).The Operational Transformation (OT) model addresses concurrency by transforming the operations of one user to ensure compatibility with those of others.11 This involves representing each edit as an operation, such as inserting, deleting, or updating text, and then adjusting these operations based on the sequence of previously executed concurrent operations.12 OT is a mature technology widely adopted in existing collaborative editors like Google Docs.15
However, the complexity of implementing OT, particularly for rich text editing, can be substantial.16
context_after: The underlying data structures in CRDTs, while optimized for consistency, might not always intuitively represent complex formatting intentions.18Vendors responding to this RFP are required to specify the conflict resolution model they propose (OT or CRDT), provide a detailed rationale for their choice, and elaborate on the specific algorithm they will employ.
This explanation should include a thorough description of how the algorithm handles various concurrent editing scenarios, such as simultaneous insertion, deletion, and formatting.

context_before: Beyond built-in tools, third-party API monitoring tools offer more advanced functionalities and often support monitoring across multiple API providers.34 Tools like Moesif provide detailed API analytics and user behavior insights 37, while Postman API Monitors allow for automated testing and monitoring.35 Datadog offers comprehensive monitoring across infrastructure, logs, and applications, including detailed API performance metrics.38 Prometheus, an open-source monitoring solution, is often used in conjunction with Alertmanager for robust alerting in complex environments.37 Uptrends focuses on API uptime and performance monitoring with global checkpoint coverage.45 These third-party solutions often provide greater flexibility in creating custom dashboards, setting up sophisticated alerts, and integrating with a wider range of notification systems.
To effectively manage throttling, it is crucial to track specific key metrics related to API usage.

The total number of API calls provides a fundamental measure of consumption.1 Monitoring error rates, particularly the occurrence of 429 "Too Many Requests" errors, indicates when throttling limits are being hit.1 Request latency and response times can also be indicators of potential throttling or performance degradation under heavy load.34 Throughput, measured as the number of requests processed per unit of time (e.g., per second, minute, or hour), helps understand the volume of API traffic.34 Finally, tracking quota usage against the defined limits, whether rate limits or monthly quotas, is essential for proactive management.20
context_after: Exploring Built-in Alerting Capabilities from API ProvidersMany API providers offer built-in alerting capabilities that can be configured to notify users when their API usage approaches or exceeds defined thresholds.

For example, an alarm can be set to trigger when the number of API requests exceeds a certain percentage of the monthly quota.

context_before: This report outlines the definition and importance of data retention policies, common retention periods for different types of user data, the technical implementation of soft and hard delete processes, methods for scheduling automated tasks in UTC, the legal implications and processes for implementing data legal holds, how user subscription status can condition data retention, the setup of automated alerts for system failures, and best practices for ensuring data integrity and compliance throughout the implementation of this automated data deletion policy.2.
Introduction: The Imperative of Automated Data Deletion:

The exponential growth in the volume of user data collected by organizations presents significant challenges, including escalating storage costs and heightened risks of security breaches.1 Effective management of this data lifecycle is crucial, and manual deletion processes are increasingly inadequate to handle the scale and complexity of modern data repositories.
context_after: The implementation of automated data deletion offers numerous benefits, including a reduction in storage expenses, improved organization of data assets, enhanced security by minimizing the amount of retained data, and a greater assurance of compliance with evolving legal frameworks.1

This report delves into the critical aspects of establishing such an automated system, addressing the specific requirements outlined by the privacy team and providing a foundation for a robust and compliant data lifecycle management strategy.3.

Understanding Data Retention Policies in Data Privacy:3.1 Definition of Data Retention Policy:A data retention policy serves as an organization's documented protocol for managing the lifecycle of its data, detailing how data is saved, maintained, and eventually disposed of in accordance with regulatory and contractual obligations.1

Communications related to a specific business activity or project at UWRF may be retained for six months after the completion of the activity or project.30 Records pertaining to audits or reviews, especially under regulations like SOX, often require retention for five to seven years.5 When determining message retention periods, organizations must prioritize legal and regulatory requirements, particularly those applicable to industries like finance or healthcare.

context_before: Furthermore, hard deletion can introduce complexities related to referential integrity, particularly when dealing with foreign key relationships in the database.

If related data in other tables depends on the record being deleted, the deletion can fail or lead to inconsistencies unless properly managed, for example, by using database constraints like ON DELETE CASCADE (which automatically deletes related records) or ON DELETE SET NULL (which sets the foreign key to null), or by handling these dependencies within the application logic.47 When implementing hard deletion, it is crucial to carefully consider its impact on referential integrity and how related data will be handled.33 Organizations must also ensure that their hard deletion processes align with compliance requirements for permanent data erasure, such as those stipulated by GDPR.38 Given the irreversible nature of hard deletion, it is often prudent to maintain an audit log or archive of the deleted records, especially if there is a potential need for historical reference or compliance verification.39

In situations where soft deletion was previously employed, organizations need to consider how hard deletion will interact with any unique key constraints that might still be in place due to soft-deleted records.43 For data warehousing purposes, understanding how hard deletes are detected in source systems is also important.
context_after: Scheduling Automated Deletion Tasks in UTC:6.1 Importance of UTC:Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is the standard time zone used as the basis for civil time today.
When scheduling automated tasks like data deletion, using UTC is crucial for ensuring consistent timing regardless of the server's physical location or the local time zones of users.52

This is particularly important for a daily purge scheduled at 02:00 UTC, as it guarantees that this deletion process occurs at the same absolute point in time globally, avoiding the complexities and potential errors associated with daylight saving time transitions and the multitude of regional time zones.

errors.sentence: Furthermore, the repercussions extend beyond the courtroom, with the potential for increased legal fees, intensified discovery efforts, and further sanctions, all of which can escalate costs and strain an organization's resources.101 Additionally, companies risk substantial reputational damage if they mishandle the legal hold process, potentially undermining client trust and business relationships.1017.3 Processes for Implementing Data Legal Holds:The implementation of data legal holds involves a series of critical steps.
context_before: The legal hold is initiated through a notice or communication from legal counsel, directing the organization to suspend the normal disposition or processing of records, including routine data deletion practices, backup tape recycling, and other data management activities.89

The purpose of a legal hold is to avoid the intentional or inadvertent destruction of evidence that might be needed in legal proceedings, thereby preventing spoliation.84 Legal holds apply to both physical documents and electronically stored information (ESI), encompassing any relevant electronic data regardless of its format or storage method.887.2 Legal Implications of Not Implementing Legal Holds:Failure to implement legal holds appropriately can have severe legal and financial ramifications for an organization.

The most significant implication is the potential for spoliation of evidence, which refers to the destruction, alteration, or loss of information that is relevant to pending or foreseeable litigation.86 Courts possess significant authority to impose sanctions for the failure to preserve evidence, ranging from monetary fines to more severe actions such as dismissing claims or instructing the jury to draw adverse inferences against the party responsible for the spoliation.101 Mishandling legal holds can also significantly weaken a party's legal position, potentially leading to unfavorable settlements or judgments, as the strength of a case often depends on the integrity and availability of the evidence preserved through a proper legal hold process.101
context_after: The process typically begins with a triggering event, such as the anticipation of litigation, the receipt of a notice of a lawsuit or legal claim, or the initiation of an internal investigation.85 Following this, the organization must identify custodians, which are individuals within the company who possess or control potentially relevant information.85 This often requires close collaboration between the legal, HR, and IT teams to ensure all key employees with relevant knowledge and access are identified.85 Next, the legal team must define the scope of the legal hold, specifying the topic or project covered, the relevant time frame, and the types of electronic or physical records that need to be preserved.85 Once the custodians and scope are defined, a legal hold notice is issued.

This formal document communicates the obligation to preserve potentially relevant evidence to the identified custodians.84 A well-drafted notice contextualizes the issue, provides a detailed description of the time requirements and types of data to be preserved, and includes contact information for any questions.84 Managing the custodian responses is also crucial, involving tracking acknowledgments of receipt and understanding of the legal hold

notice.85 It is important to follow up with any custodians who do not respond to ensure compliance.88 The next step is the actual preservation of data, which involves ensuring that the identified data is not deleted or altered.

context_before: notice.85 It is important to follow up with any custodians who do not respond to ensure compliance.88 The next step is the actual preservation of data, which involves ensuring that the identified data is not deleted or altered.
This often requires suspending the organization's routine data deletion policies and implementing measures such as in-place holds on electronic data or copying data to a secure location.84

The IT department typically plays a vital role in executing these technical preservation measures.84 Given that legal holds can sometimes last for extended periods, it is good practice to maintain ongoing communication and reminders with custodians and IT personnel to ensure they remain aware of the hold's status and their obligations.84 Throughout the process, meticulous tracking and auditing of all legal hold activities are essential to demonstrate a defensible process in case the organization's preservation efforts are ever questioned.87 Finally, once the legal matter is resolved or the need for the hold ends, the organization must formally release the legal hold, notifying all custodians that their preservation obligations are lifted and they can resume normal data management practices.857.4 Impact of Legal Holds on Data Deletion Policies:Data that is subject to a legal hold must be explicitly excluded from any automated data deletion processes, irrespective of the standard data retention period defined in the organization's

Ensure that the data retention policy is fully aligned with all relevant legal frameworks, including GDPR, CCPA, and HIPAA 1, and regularly review and update the policy to reflect any changes in legislation.1 Adhere strictly to the principle of data minimization, retaining personal data only for as long as it is absolutely necessary for the specified purposes.4 Implement secure data deletion methods, especially for hard deletes, to prevent any possibility of data recovery 1; overwriting data is a common and effective technique.154 Honor users' rights, including the right to be forgotten (data erasure), by establishing clear and efficient processes for hard deletion when requested and where legally mandated.4 Maintain clear and comprehensive documentation of the data retention policy, the specific deletion procedures implemented, and all compliance efforts undertaken.1 Conduct regular audits of data retention and deletion practices to proactively identify any potential compliance gaps or areas for improvement.3 Provide thorough training to employees on the organization's data retention policies and the correct procedures for secure data deletion.1 Establish well-defined legal hold procedures to ensure that any data required for legal matters is explicitly excluded from the automated deletion processes.5

If the organization utilizes third-party vendors who handle user data, ensure that their data retention and deletion practices also comply with all relevant requirements.153 Finally, consider the use of data anonymization or pseudonymization techniques as potential alternatives to outright deletion in certain situations, particularly for data that is used for analytics purposes where direct personal identifiers are not necessary.11911. errors.sentence: The primary objective of such a dashboard is to provide actionable insights that support informed decision-making across various levels of an organization.1Interactive dashboards serve several crucial goals.
context_before: Interactive Dashboard Embedding: A Consultant-Style Scope DocumentOverviewThe implementation of an interactive data dashboard represents a strategic move towards enhancing data understanding and analysis within organizations.

This digital interface is designed to display data and information in a dynamic and human-friendly manner, empowering users to actively engage with the data to extract meaningful insights.1 Unlike traditional static reports that present a fixed view of information, an interactive dashboard allows users to manipulate data through elements such as charts, graphs, filters, and buttons.
This enables real-time customization of data visualizations, facilitating a deeper exploration and understanding of key metrics.1
context_after: They enable users to delve into the granular details of data, offering both macro and micro perspectives on business performance.3

This capability for agile decision-making ensures that business-related questions can be answered with the most current information available.3 Furthermore, these dashboards empower business users to conduct immediate analysis, reducing their reliance on IT departments and saving valuable resources.3 By presenting a real-time snapshot of business performance, interactive dashboards allow for the quick identification of trends and the monitoring of key performance indicators (KPIs), which is essential for proactive management and strategic adjustments.5 Enhanced visibility into organizational health is another significant benefit, as these dashboards consolidate key metrics from various departments into a single interface.6 Ultimately, the transformation of raw data into easily digestible visual formats democratizes data access and improves data analysis and decision-making processes, contributing to overall business success.2

The real-time engagement offered by interactive dashboards encourages users to explore trends and uncover insights more effectively than static reports.7 By connecting to multiple data sources, these dashboards provide a holistic view of information in one central platform, eliminating the need for users to navigate disparate systems.8

errors.sentence: This authenticated encryption algorithm ensures both data confidentiality and integrity, guarding against unauthorized access and tampering.
context_before:
**Feasibility Study: Secure Sharing with Verifiable Logs**

---

### **Objective – Secure Sharing with Verifiable Logs**

This feasibility study explores the development and deployment of a secure data-sharing system with verifiable audit logs, tailored to highly regulated environments.

The primary objective is to enable entities (e.g., enterprises, healthcare providers, government agencies) to share sensitive data across organizational boundaries without compromising confidentiality, integrity, or regulatory compliance.

The solution ensures that:

- Data is encrypted before leaving the client’s environment.
- Access and sharing actions are logged in a tamper-proof manner.
- Regulatory frameworks such as GDPR are upheld.
- Stakeholders retain cryptographic proof of compliance activities.

---

### **Encryption Model – Client-Side AES-GCM with Key Escrow via KMS-Backed HSM**

To ensure end-to-end confidentiality, all data is encrypted on the client side using **AES-GCM (Advanced Encryption Standard in Galois/Counter Mode)** before transmission or storage.
context_after:
Key characteristics of the encryption model include:

- **Client-side encryption**: Data is encrypted before it leaves the user’s device or service boundary.
- **AES-GCM*
*: Offers authenticated encryption with additional data (AEAD), ensuring integrity in transit and at rest.

errors.sentence: The nature of the business problem, specifically whether the goal is classification, regression, or forecasting, will dictate the types of models that are suitable.6 The characteristics of the available data, including its volume, structure (structured vs. unstructured), and whether it exhibits time-dependent patterns, are also critical considerations.6
context_before: Enterprise applications commonly leverage a variety of models, each with unique strengths tailored to specific analytical tasks.4 Classification models, such as Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, and Random Forests, are effective for predicting categorical outcomes like customer churn or fraud detection.4 Regression models, including Linear Regression and Time Series models, are suited for forecasting continuous numerical values such as sales figures or resource demand.4 Time Series models, such as ARIMA and Exponential Smoothing, are specifically designed to analyze and forecast data that changes over time.4 Clustering models like K-Means are valuable for grouping data points with similar characteristics, enabling customer segmentation or anomaly detection.4 Anomaly detection models are specifically used to identify unusual patterns in data, which can be critical for flagging fraudulent activities or cybersecurity threats.4Each of these models presents distinct advantages and disadvantages within the enterprise context.

Linear Regression offers simplicity and ease of interpretation, making it suitable for exploratory data analysis and identifying relationships between variables.11 However, it assumes a linear relationship between variables and can be significantly affected by outliers.15 Logistic Regression is highly effective for binary classification problems and provides interpretable probability estimates.8 Its limitations include the assumption of linearity in the log-odds and potential instability in the presence of multicollinearity.22 Decision Trees are easily interpretable and can handle both categorical and numerical data.9

However, they are prone to overfitting, especially with complex datasets, and can be sensitive to small variations in the training data.30 Random Forests typically achieve high accuracy and are robust to noise and outliers due to their ensemble nature.10 Their primary drawbacks are reduced interpretability compared to single decision trees and higher computational costs.37 Time Series models excel at capturing temporal dependencies and forecasting future values based on historical patterns.12 They often assume stationarity in the data and can be sensitive to the quality and completeness of historical data.50The selection of a specific predictive analytics model is guided by several key factors.
context_after: The level of importance placed on model interpretability and explainability will influence the choice, as simpler models often offer greater transparency.7 The required accuracy and performance of the model, along with the available computational resources and scalability needs, will further narrow down the options.6 Ultimately, the choice of model must align with the overarching business objectives and any specific constraints, such as regulatory requirements or latency limitations.54Maintaining the accuracy and relevance of predictive analytics models necessitates a robust retraining strategy.
As underlying data patterns evolve over time, models can become less accurate, a phenomenon known as concept drift.54

Therefore, retraining is essential to ensure the continued reliability of predictions.56 The frequency of retraining is not uniform and depends on the stability of the data and the rate at which these underlying patterns change.57 Strategies for retraining include periodic retraining at fixed intervals (e.g., daily, weekly, or monthly), event-triggered retraining which occurs when model performance drops below a predefined threshold, and continuous learning where models are updated with new data in near real-time.58 Methodologies for retraining can involve full retraining on the entire updated dataset, incremental retraining where only new data is used to update the model, or leveraging techniques like transfer learning to utilize knowledge gained from previous training cycles.61Custom Model Training Workflow – secure sandbox, CI/CD for ML.A secure sandbox environment is a fundamental component of a robust custom model training workflow.

Establishing a secure sandbox involves several key security considerations and best practices.

Strict access controls, adhering to the principle of least privilege, are essential to ensure that only authorized personnel can access the environment and specific resources within it.64 Data encryption, both at rest and during transit, is crucial to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access.64 Network segmentation and isolation further enhance security by limiting the potential impact of a breach.64 Regular vulnerability scanning and patching are necessary to identify and remediate any security weaknesses in the sandbox environment.62 Secure data ingestion and sanitization processes are vital to prevent the introduction of malicious or corrupted data.66 Finally, comprehensive monitoring and logging of all activities within the sandbox provide visibility into user actions and potential security incidents.62Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) principles, when applied to machine learning workflows, form the practice of MLOps.

errors.sentence: Adherence to SOC 2 compliance standards is paramount for service organizations handling customer data.
context_before: For Service Level Agreement (SLA) breach notifications, AI can continuously monitor service performance against predefined SLAs, providing real-time visibility into adherence.59 The system can automatically trigger alerts when performance metrics fall below agreed-upon thresholds, enabling timely intervention.59

Furthermore, AI's analytical capabilities allow for the prediction of potential SLA breaches by analyzing historical performance data and identifying trends that might lead to future violations.59 Best practices for implementing such a system include clearly defining the objectives and key performance indicators (KPIs) for AI-driven Service Level Management (SLM) 78, ensuring the availability of high-quality and relevant data for accurate predictions 78, seamlessly integrating the alerting system with existing service management platforms 78, carefully configuring alert thresholds to minimize alert fatigue from excessive notifications 59, and utilizing multiple communication channels to ensure alerts are received promptly.59Sentiment-based triggers leverage the power of AI-powered sentiment analysis to understand customer emotions expressed across various communication channels, including text, audio, and video.81

The alerting system can be configured to trigger notifications when negative sentiment, as identified by the AI, exceeds a specified threshold, indicating potential customer dissatisfaction or issues requiring immediate attention.80 Advanced AI models can even discern nuanced sentiments within a single customer interaction, providing a more granular understanding of their emotional state.83 Implementing sentiment-based alerting effectively involves employing sophisticated Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to accurately interpret the context and subtleties of human language 81, carefully setting sentiment thresholds to ensure relevant alerts are generated 80, integrating sentiment analysis capabilities with Customer Relationship Management (CRM) systems to provide a holistic view of customer interactions and sentiment history 78, combining sentiment triggers with other relevant contextual factors to enhance the accuracy and relevance of alerts 80, and incorporating a human review process to validate the AI's sentiment classifications, especially for complex or ambiguous interactions.83SOC 2 Compliance – logging, change management, access reviews.
context_after: Logging plays a critical role in meeting SOC 2 requirements.

It necessitates the comprehensive recording of system activities, including all access attempts, modifications to system configurations, and any security-related events.2 These logs must be stored securely, protected against unauthorized access or tampering, and retained according to defined policies.2 Regular review and thorough analysis of these logs are essential for the timely detection and effective response to any security incidents that may arise.2SOC 2 compliance also mandates the implementation of robust change management procedures.
These formal processes are crucial for controlling and meticulously documenting all modifications made to systems, applications, and underlying infrastructure.2

errors.sentence: Implementing edge computing clusters is a key strategy for achieving this.
context_before: OTA software updates using digital signatures is a fundamental security practice.

Every OTA update should be digitally signed by the vehicle manufacturer or a trusted authority to guarantee its authenticity and integrity.45 This digital signature acts as a tamper-proof seal, verifying that the software update originates from a legitimate source and has not been altered or corrupted during transmission.45 Before installing any OTA update, the vehicle's onboard system must be capable of verifying the digital signature using a corresponding public key.45

If the signature verification fails, indicating that the update may be from an untrusted source or has been tampered with, the installation process should be aborted to prevent the introduction of malicious software or compromised code.45 To effectively manage the cryptographic keys and control the validity period of digital signatures, the use of X.509 certificates is highly recommended.53 These certificates provide a standardized format for public key certificates, including information about the certificate holder, the issuing authority, and the validity period, allowing for better management and revocation of keys if necessary.53Scalability RoadmapTo ensure the solution can handle a growing number of connected vehicles and increasing data volumes, a robust scalability roadmap is essential.

errors.sentence: The current translation API does not account for locale-specific datetime parsing, leading to incorrect message timings and potential miscommunication in scheduling or event-based conversations.
context_before:
**Problem**  
In Microsoft Teams bilingual chats, machine translation between Spanish and English often misinterprets AM/PM time expressions.
This is due to differences in datetime formats—Spanish commonly uses 24-hour notation or places AM/PM differently, while English relies on 12-hour formats with explicit AM/PM suffixes.
context_after:
**Fix**  
Integrate a pre-processing layer that applies locale-aware datetime regular expressions before passing messages to the translation API.
This layer identifies and standardizes time expressions based on source and target language conventions.
For Spanish-to-English, 24-hour times will be converted to 12-hour format with appropriate AM/PM context.

errors.sentence: Access tokens associated with the chatbot export system were rotated to ensure no additional unauthorized access could occur.
context_before: The incident was caused by a faulty `JOIN` clause in the export cron job script, which failed to properly filter records based on the correct `tenant_id`.
As a result, rows belonging to different tenants were joined and included in the same export payload.

**Immediate Mitigation:**  
Upon detection, the exported file was immediately purged from the server, and the public link was revoked to prevent further access.
context_after: The recipient was promptly notified and confirmed deletion of the file on their end.
**Long-Term Fix:**
A tenant filter has been explicitly added to the export query to ensure only data from the requesting tenant is included.

**SCORM 1.2のトラッキング:** プラットフォームにはSCORM 1.2 APIのサーバーサイド実装が含まれています。コンテンツがサーバー上で実行される際、内部でSCORM APIを呼び出して学習者の進捗を追跡します（完了状況、スコア、学習時間、インタラクション詳細の記録）。これらのトラッキングデータはプラットフォームのデータベースに安全に保存され、必要に応じて既存のLMSと同期することも可能です。クライアント側のスクリプトに頼らず、受講者の進捗と結果が確実に記録されます。
5.

**xAPIイベントの記録:** xAPIベースのコンテンツの場合、サーバーが学習体験のイベントを捕捉し、対応するxAPIステートメントを生成します。これらのステートメントは統合されたLRSに送信され、または必要に応じて外部のLRSに転送されます。すべてのインタラクションがサーバーで仲介されるため、ユーザーが一時的にオフラインになっても各xAPIステートメントが確実に記録されます（接続が回復次第、システムがステートメントを送信します）。
6.

**セキュリティとスケーラビリティ:** すべてのデータ通信はSSL暗号化により保護されています。本プラットフォームはセキュアなクラウドネットワーク環境（例えばアクセス制限されたVPC内）で稼働しています。各コンポーネントはコンテナ化されており、安定性を保ちながらユーザー数に応じて水平スケーリングが可能です。トレーニングのロジックをサーバー上のWebAssemblyで実行することで、サンドボックス化による追加のセキュリティ層を提供します。さらに、サーバーサイドレンダリングによりクライアント側に露出するデータを最小限に抑えています。本アーキテクチャは高可用性と障害復旧にも対応しており、定期バックアップやフェイルオーバー機能によってサービス継続性を確保します。

*フェーズ2：設計およびアーキテクチャ設定 (週3〜4):** システムの設計とアーキテクチャを確定します。クラウド環境をセットアップし（サーバー、データベース、サービスのプロビジョニング）、コンテンツ配信の準備を行います。SCORMおよびxAPIコンテンツの構成とアクセス方法を計画します。

初回の打ち合わせでプロジェクトの範囲と目標を確認します。ステークホルダーから詳細な要件を収集し、成功基準と成果物を定義します。コミュニケーション計画とプロジェクトスケジュールを策定します。

context_after:
**フェーズ3：開発と構成 (週5〜8):** プラットフォームの各モジュールを設定し、WebAssemblyコンテンツエンジンおよびSSRフロントエンドコンポーネントを構築します。必要に応じてカスタム機能や統合機能（例：SSO連携やカスタムレポート）を開発します。SCORM 1.2コースのサンプルを導入し、xAPIエンドポイントとLRSの設定を行います。
4.

**フェーズ4：テストと品質保証 (週9〜12):** システムの徹底的なテストを実施します。SCORMおよびxAPIの機能に関するユニットテスト・統合テストに加え、パイロットユーザーによる受入テストを行います。クライアント側スクリプトなしでコンテンツが正しく動作し、すべてのトラッキングデータ（SCORMとxAPI）が正確に記録されることを確認します。検出された問題を修正し、パフォーマンスを最適化します。
5. *

*フェーズ5：本番展開とローンチ (週13〜14):** 本番クラウド環境にソリューションをデプロイし、最終確認を実施します。必要に応じて一部ユーザーでのソフトローンチを行います。管理者（および該当する場合はインストラクター）に新システムの利用方法についてトレーニングを提供します。安定性を確認した後、全ユーザーにプラットフォームを本格展開します。

errors.sentence: This ensures that the QASM program is well-formed before any execution attempt.
context_before: These are not syntax errors but potential logic bugs, and should be reported as warnings.
Collectively, these checks will catch common QASM mistakes such as undeclared qubits, duplicate registers, wrong gate arity, type errors, and unreachable or ill-formed code.

For example, if a gate name is undefined, the analyzer should produce a compile-time error (“gate X undefined”) ([Support `extern` gate declarations  · Issue #507 · openqasm/openqasm · GitHub](https://github.com/openqasm/openqasm/issues/507#:~:text=In%20this%20case%2C%20long%20before,them%20available%20to%20the%20user)) rather than silently proceeding.

## Error Taxonomy  
Errors and warnings generated by the parser/analyzer are classified as follows:

- **Syntax Errors:**
These are violations of the QASM grammar detected by the parser.
context_after: A syntax error halts parsing and reports the offending line and expected tokens.
For instance, writing `qreg q[3]` without a semicolon would be a syntax error.

errors.sentence: Technically, each device’s identity record will use a UUID4 value as its primary key.
context_before: Even generating 10^15 UUIDs yields only a 10^-9 collision probability ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=%7B1%7D%7B1)).
Thus, using 128-bit IDs makes accidental collisions effectively impossible in any realistic fleet size.
(By comparison, a 48-bit MAC address space is only ~2.8×10^14 large – much smaller – and is already known to produce occasional duplicates.)
context_after: Generation should be backed by a cryptographically-secure RNG to ensure full 128-bit entropy.

This probabilistic fix **dramatically shrinks collision risk**: even under worst-case birthday estimates, an attacker or error would need to generate on the order of 2^64 IDs before seeing a collision ([random - UUID collisions - Software Engineering Stack Exchange](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/130261/uuid-collisions#:~:text=A%20suggestion%3A%20tread%20very%20carefully,of%20entropy%20in%20each%20key))
(and only if the RNG were perfect).

errors.sentence: This breaks connectivity for both hosts.
context_before: **Network/MAC-layer collisions** occur when two devices share a network address.

Duplicate MAC addresses on a switched LAN make the switch’s MAC table oscillate: each new frame forces the switch to relearn the source port, causing traffic for that MAC to flap between ports ([networking - Duplicate MAC address on the same LAN possible?
- Server Fault](https://serverfault.com/questions/462178/duplicate-mac-address-on-the-same-lan-possible#:~:text=So%20if%20there%20are%20two,and%20off%20and%20be%20inconsistent)).
context_after: In switching networks a duplicate MAC “makes switching unreliable” and can disrupt ARP/NDP mappings ([How to solve problem with two devices with the same MAC address, connected to the switch?

- Network Engineering Stack Exchange](https://networkengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/83041/how-to-solve-problem-with-two-devices-with-the-same-mac-address-connected-to-th#:~:text=You%20can%27t%20have%20two%20devices,like%20with%20ARP%20or%20NDP)).
In severe cases, managed switches trigger port-security or even shut down a port when detecting a duplicate MAC on multiple ports ([networking - Duplicate MAC address on the same LAN possible?

errors.sentence: As standardized in RFC 4122, UUIDs are 128-bit values designed to be globally unique without a central authority ([](https://nostarch.com/download/EngineeringSecureDevices_Chapter6.pdf#:~:text=clear,Linux%20RNG%2C%20as%20shown%20in)).
context_before: Finally, physical-layer collisions result in **battery exhaustion**: a constant stream of conflicting frames triggers retransmissions, draining device power and crippling the network ([](https://www.ijcst.org/Volume13/Issue2/p1_13_2.pdf#:~:text=%E2%80%A2%20Exhaustion%20Attack%20Jamming%20or,way%20to%20lessen%20the%20network)).
In sum, collisions can lead to data loss, device unavailability, and even serve as precursors to larger attacks.

## Probabilistic Fix (128-bit UID)  
To virtually eliminate identifier collisions, this plan mandates using **128-bit universally unique IDs (UUIDs)** for all device identities.
context_after: In practice the collision probability is astronomically small.

For truly random (version-4) 128-bit UUIDs, the number needed for a 50% collision chance is on the order of 2.7×10^18 ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20the%20number%20of,27)).

That equals generating one billion UUIDs per second for 86 years ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20the%20number%20of,27)).

errors.sentence: To enhance data integrity in cryogenic organ storage, implement a triple CRC32 checksum on combined RFID and temperature telemetry packets.
context_after: This redundancy ensures robust validation during transmission and mitigates silent corruption in high-noise environments.
Any organ bin exhibiting LN₂ probe temperature drift exceeding ±0.3 Kelvin from baseline must be auto-rejected to prevent transplant risk from thermal instability.
The legacy COBOL subroutine CHK3SUM must be adapted to interface with the existing IoT bridge, enabling seamless checksum verification across both legacy and modern systems.
